CATALYSIS A: GENE ELSEVIER Applied CatalysisA:General132(1995)97-109 Alcohol synthesis from syngas over supported molybdenum catalysts Y. Avila a, C. Kappenstein b, S. Pronier b, J. Barrault b Interep, Los Tegues. Apdo 76343, Caracas, 1070 A, Venezuela Laboratoire de Catalyse en Chimie Organigue, URA CNRS 350, 40 ar. Recteur Pineau, 86022 Poitiers cedex, France Received 10 April 1995; revised 18 June 1995; accepted 23 June 1995 Abstract Light alcohols as well as hydrocarbons can be obtained from the selective conversion of syngas over supported molybdenum catalysts. It is shown in this study that the activity and the selectivity are very much dependent on the support, the molybdenum content and the alkaline promoter. Indeed the methanol selectivity improves when molybdenum is supported on zinc oxide and promoted with potassium. Moreover, we found that the rate of methanol formation is in good correlation with unreduced molybdenum species. A dual-site mechanism is proposed for the methanol synthesis on such catalysts involving hydrogen activation (and dissociative carbon monoxide adsorption for hydrocarbons formation) and non-dissociative carbon monoxide adsorption, respectively, on reduced and unreduced molybdenum species. Kevslords: (CO, H,) reaction; Methanol synthesis; Molybdenum catalysts 1. Introduction Molybdenum catalysts have been recognized to be effective for the methanation and/or for the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis of hydrocarbons. Saito and Anderson [ 1 ] investigated unsupported molybdenum catalysts including oxides, carbides, oxicarbides, sulphides or nitrides and concluded that the specific activity of these catalysts was comparable to that of the best metallic catalysts. Tatsumi et al. [2] described the effect of the support and of alkali additives on the behavior of molybdenum catalysts for alcohol synthesis and found that the yield and selectivity to alcohols depend very much on the operating conditions. Arila et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 132 (1995) 97-109 and additives strongly affected the catalytic properties [3-7]. Molybdenum-silica catalysts were active in the formation of C,-CS alcohols [3-7] and the addition of KCl to that catalyst resulted in a significant increase of the alcohol selectivity [ 8 ] . Youchang et al. [9] found that on MoSZ the selectivity to alcohols was much affected by KIC03 promotion. The increase of the K,C03 content did not change the conversion significantly but greatly increased the alcohol selectivity. On the other hand there is evidence that the activity of unsupported molybdenum species in the syngas conversion to hydrocarbons increases when the reduction of active species increases [ 10] . Tatsumi et al. [4,5 ] also found that the hydrocarbon formation was correlated with extensively reduced molybdenum species in the case of SiO, supported catalysts. Saito and Anderson [ 11 ] also investigated the activity of molybdenum species for the production of hydrocarbons and reported that zerovalent molybdenum gave higher hydrocarbons with a higher activity than molybdenum oxides. Muramatsu et al. [ 12] reported that the alcohol formation required two kinds of molybdenum species; metallic and Mo02. The present paper reports on the catalytic properties of molybdenum supported and K-promoted materials for the formation of alcohols. The interaction between support, potassium promoter and the molybdenum component were examined based upon characterization by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), and probe molecule chemisorption. The catalyst characterization and catalytic properties for alcohol synthesis were correlated. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalyst preparation Catalysts were prepared by impregnation of different supports with an aqueous solution of ammonium heptamolybdate, (and KN03 for promoted catalysts) dried at 120 and calcined at 300 for 4 h. 2.2. (CO, Hz) reaction The syngas conversion was carried out under pressure in a continuous system with a fixed bed reactor under the following standard conditions: P = 4 MPa, F=10 1 h-', HZ/CO=2, Wcatd,=10 g, T=250. The catalyst was diluted with carborundum (Prolabo) (1 /2) in order to minimize the diffusional effects due to heat transfer. Moreover, during catalytic experiments, there was no significant variation of the temperature profile in the catalyst bed ( 2 K). Reagents and products were analyzed on line with gas phase chromatographs, (i) CO CO2, C,, C.,, C3 on Porapak Q (TC Detector) and (ii) hydrocarbons, oxygenates on CP-SIL-5 (Fl Detector). Before use all the catalysts were reduced `in situ' with hydrogen at 500 for 10 h. Catalyst characterization XRD Structural characterization of the samples was carried out by X-ray powder diffraction with a Philips Model 1710 Diffractometer [Cu Ka radiation (45 kV and 30 mA) ] . BET The measurements were made with a Flowsorb 11 Model 2300 operating at the temperature of liquid nitrogen with a (30 NZ-70 He) mixture as adsorption gas. Before BET analysis all the samples were heated at 523 K for 1 h. TPR and carbon. monoxide adsorption TPR was carried out in a quartz reactor. Each sample was placed in a argon flow, degassed at the final temperature of the TPR for one hour and cooled down to room temperature. Then calibrated quantities (pulses) of hydrogen were introduced while the temperature was raised to 1073 K at a rate of 4 K min-'. The final oxidation state of molybdenum could then be calculated from the total amount of hydrogen consumed, assuming that the original oxidation number was Movt. The chemisorption of carbon monoxide, was carried out with the same equipment. Each catalyst was reduced and evacuated at 773 K. After cooling down to room temperature. pulses of carbon monoxide were introduced until saturation. XPS The XPS spectra of supported catalysts were recorded using ISA-RIBER equipment with the AlKa excitation radiation at 1486.6 eV and analyzed using RIBERCAMECA software. Physicochemical characterization XRD The different phases in the solids before and after the reaction were determined by XRD. Table 2 gives the results obtained with the different solids used. In the Cr203 and ZnCr204 supports no trace of any crystalline phase of molybdenum was detected either because it did not exist or because the size of the crystals was too small to be detected by the technique employed. In molybdenum catalysts, an interaction between molybdenum and zinc oxide can be observed resulting from the formation before the reaction of the aZnM004 phase and after reaction of the ZnM003 phase. M003 (hex.) can be observed when ZrO, is the support. TPR Support effect. Results presented in Fig. 1 show that the reduction temperature of molybdenum species depends on the support. The reducibility is highest when molybdenum is supported on chromium oxide, and decreases in the order zinc chromite, zirconium oxide and zinc oxide. Moreover for the first two catalysts it seems that the support is involved in the hydrogen activation so that molybdenum species are reduced at a lower temperature. These results show that the existence of molybdenum-support interactions affect strongly the reducibility of molybdenum oxide as reported by Stampl et al. [ 131. The average molybdenum oxidation state presented in Table 3 also demonstrated that zinc oxide also had an effect on molybdenum species as reported in previous works on copper-zinc oxide catalysts [14,15]. This result is in agreement with the hypothesis that carbon monoxide adsorption occurs on the more reduced sites [4,5,10,11 ] . The support has a very significant effect on the catalytic activity of molybdenum, in agreement with the results obtained by Tatsumi et al. [3,6,19]. The best activity is obtained when the molybdenum is deposited on ZrOz, however the selectivity towards methanol of this catalyst is very low. The study of the effect of contact time on the distribution of the products for Mo/Zr02 shows that methanol is a primary product of the reaction [ 18] . Therefore the support ZrO, could participate in the transformation of methanol into hydrocarbons. When the support is changed the specific activity decreases and the selectivity for oxygenated compounds increases in the following order; Zr02 < ZnCr204 < Cr203 < ZnO, which is in agreement with the basicity of the surfaces. Under the experimental conditions employed, Zn0 appears to be the best support for the production of light alcohols from syngas. Over Zn0 supported catalysts, the dissociative adsorption of carbon monoxide is not important as already observed in our laboratory [20]. These results show the existence of molybdenum support interaction which modifies substantially the activity and selectivity in the transformation of syngas. This interaction can affect the adsorption of carbon monoxide and the possible secondary transformation of alcohols. The existence of this interaction on the Mo/ ZnC03 catalyst system is confirmed (when calcined the system is similar to the Mo/Zn0 catalyst) . The activity of the above catalyst is similar to that of Mo/ZnO, however its selectivity to methanol decreases significantly compared to that of Mo / ZnO. These results show, once again that Mo-support interactions play an important role in the catalytic behavior of molybdenum. The change of the carbon monoxide conversion as function of reaction time are shown in Fig. 4. With zinc chromite and Zr02 there is a short induction time. For Cr203 a slow deactivation can be noticed. Effect of the molybdenum content and of potassium additive. We studied the effect of the molybdenum content on Mo/ZnO, the best system for producing light alcohols. Table 9 shows that the specific activity decreases when the molybdenum content increases, whereas the selectivity to methanol passes through a maximum around 10% molybdenum. The decrease in activity could be the consequence of a decrease in the molybdenum-support interactions. These results lead us to think that: (a) a significant dispersion of the active phase is necessary to obtain an high activity and, (b) it is difficult to increase the activity by only increasing the molybdenum content due to the dispersion changes and different molybdenum species are formed at the ZnO surface. Addition of potassium (0.3%) to the system [MO10/Zn0] reduced the activity of the catalyst but increased specifically the selectivity to methanol with a lower selectivity to carbon dioxide. By XPS it was possible to observe the decrease of the surface dispersion of molybdenum when the potassium was added. This could explain the decrease in activity. As for the selectivity to methanol, the effect potassium has can be explained by the electronic Mo-K interactions which favor the non-dissociative adsorption of carbon monoxide and decrease the hydrogenating capacity of molybdenum [ 6,16,20] . Nevertheless, we cannot exclude that carbon monoxide dissociation and hydrocarbons formation require an ensemble of sites, the nature and the number of which could be changed by mobile support species or/and potassium promoter [21]. Relationship between catalytic properties and surface composition. The TPR results we have given show that there is a relationship between the selectivity to methanol and the fraction of unreduced molybdenum (Fig. 5) . This behavior argues in favor of non-dissociative adsorption of carbon monoxide on less reduced molybdenum species. The results of XRD and XPS show that the initial phase of our solids is molybdenum oxide (Mo03) which after reduction (or/and reaction) is transformed into Mo02. As the unreduced molybdenum species decrease when the surface molybdenum content increases, there is an inverse relationship between the methanol activity and the surface molybdenum content (Fig. 6). All these results lead us to suggest that a molybdenum-support interaction changes the reducibility of molybdenum oxides) and consequently the nature of surface species. In the case of a Mo/Zn0 system it is possible that the intermediate formation (or the presence) of zinc molybdate could inhibit the catalyst reduction and increase the methanol selectivity and activity. 4. Discussion The molybdenum based catalysts are potential solids for the production of light alcohols from syngas. The catalytic behavior of molybdenum depends very much 108 Y Arila et al. /Applied Catalvsis A: General 132 (1995) 97-709 on the support used. Indeed the reducibility of molybdenum depends on the support, with a good correlation between the selectivity to methanol and the amount of unreduced molybdenum. The properties of molybdenum catalysts are directly related to the Mo-support interactions, to the molybdenum dispersion, to the morphology of the molybdenum phase and to the reducibility of the oxide precursors and its content. The characteristics of the surface and the study of the reducibility of molybdenum as a function of the support show that the unreduced molybdenum species could depend on the dispersion. Variations in dispersion were obtained by changing the support. The Mo/ZnO system proved to be the most selective for the formation of light alcohols, its catalytic behavior being related both to the reducibility and to the dispersion of molybdenum. As the oxidation state of molybdenum decreases, its activity increases and the catalyst becomes more selective to hydrocarbons. This behavior is in agreement with the results published previously [ 1,2] which propose that hydrocarbons are formed on active sites with a metallic character, while alcohots need active sites wherein molybdenum can have an oxidation state around 4 + . The addition of potassium to Mo (10) /ZnO catalyst increases significantly the selectivity to methanol, decreasing at the same time the specific activity. The presence of potassium does not seen to alter either the reduction rate or the surface species, but decreases the dispersion of molybdenum. Some recent works revealed that for the potassium promoted samples an interaction between the promoter and the supported molybdenum component occurs [ 21 ] . Moreover it is shown that the K-Mo interaction weakens the interaction of the Movt component with the support and promotes aggregation of Mov` [21] which is in agreement with the decrease of the dispersion observed in our experiments. This interaction could influence the adsorption of hydrogen over molybdenum species and the non-dissociative adsorption of carbon monoxide involving potassium [23] especially for an optimum K/ Mo ratio of about 0.8. Lastly, as far as the mechanism of the formation of alcohols on the Mo/Zn0 system is concerned, there must exist at the surface of the solid some more reduced M00Z species next to molybdenum species which would be necessary for obtaining a C2+ alcohols production. In this type of catalysts the chain growth of the oxygenated compounds is not much favored. Hydrocarbon formation occurs over more reduced molybdenum species, which favor the dissociative adsorption of carbon monoxide as well as hydrogen activation. References [ 1 ] M. Saito and R.B. Light alcohols as well as hydrocarbons can be obtained from the selective conversion of syngas over supported molybdenum catalysts. It is shown in this study that the activity and the selectivity are very much dependent on the support, the molybdenum content and the alkaline promoter. Indeed the methanol selectivity improves when molybdenum is supported on zinc oxide and promoted with potassium. Moreover, we found that the rate of methanol formation is in good correlation with unreduced molybdenum species. A dual-site mechanism is proposed for the methanol synthesis on such catalysts involving hydrogen activation (and dissociative carbon monoxide adsorption for hydrocarbons formation) and non-dissociative carbon monoxide adsorption, respectively, on reduced and unreduced molybdenum species.
